NATURE OF CYBERBULLYING \nTraditional face to face bullying has long been recognized as a risk factor for social and emotional development of bullies, targets and bully victims during childhood and adolescence; observers are also known to be adversely affected. The advent of cyberbullying shows that offenders have turned to technology (particularly mobile phones and the internet) as a potent tool of exercising their power and control over others. Cyberbullies have the ability to reach their targets day or night.

The most common places where cyberbullying occurs are:

• Social Media, such as Facebook, Instagram, Snapchat, and TikTok 
• Text messaging and messaging apps on mobile or tablets device 
• Instant messaging, direct messaging, and online chatting over the internet 
• Online forums, chat rooms, and message boards, such as Reddit 
• Email 
• Online gaming communities

Cyberbullying by Sex and Sexual Orientation

Cyberbullying statistics differ among various groups, including: 
• Girls and boy's bot reported similar numbers when asked if they have been cyberbullied, at 23.7% and 21.9%, respectively. 
• LGBTQ adolescents report cyberbullying at higher rates, at 31.7% According to other reports, up to 56% of young people who identify as LGBTQ have experience cyberbullying. 
• Transgender teens were the most likely to be cyberbullied, at the significantly high rate of 35.4%.

ASKING FOR ADULT HELP \nBy prohibiting some websites and imposing age-appropriate restrictions on computer and internet use parents can play a significant role in prevention. Inconsistent parental supervision has been linked to an increased risk for children to engage in traditional and online bullying either as perpetrators or targets. However, once cyberbullying has started, adults could be less successful in dealing with it.

What to when cyberbullying occurs? 
1. Don't respond or retaliate: It's important not to respond to cyberbullying as this can often escalate the situation. 
2. Save the evidence: Keep a record of any messages, comments, or posts that were hurtful or abusive. This can be used as evidence later if necessary. 
3. Block the cyberbully: If the cyberbully is someone you know, block them from your social media accounts or any other platforms where they can contact you. 
4. Report the cyberbullying: Most social media platforms have options to report bullying and harassment. Use this feature to alert the platform and seek help. 
5. Seek support: Talk to someone you trust, such as a friend, family member, teacher, or counselor. They can provide emotional support and help you develop a plan to address the situation. 
6. Consider involving law enforcement: In some cases, cyberbullying can be a crime. If bullying includes threats or involves illegal activity, contact your local law enforcement agency.
